notes: Official national standard; spoken across northern and southwestern China
Considered a separate branch from Mandarin by some linguists; mainly Shanxi and nearby areas
Spoken in Shanghai, Zhejiang, southern Jiangsu; includes Shanghainese, Suzhounese
Spoken in Hunan; transitional between Mandarin and Wu
Spoken in Jiangxi and bordering provinces; closely related to Hakka
Spoken by Hakka people across Guangdong, Fujian, Jiangxi; also in Taiwan and Southeast Asia
Center in Guangzhou, Hong Kong, and Macau; widely used overseas
Highly diverse branch; includes Southern Min (Hokkien), Eastern Min, and Teochew
Spoken in southern Anhui; transitional between Wu and Gan
Spoken mainly in Guangxi; distinct from Yue though geographically adjacent
